s.text: The Louisville region is facing the potential loss of three or four staff members because of the cuts, said Dennis Bricking, executive director of the Louisville Legal Aid Society, which serves Jefferson and 14 surrounding counties.
Scott Crocker, executive director of Kentucky Legal Aid, which serves western and southern Kentucky, said his office will lose about $260,000 out of a budget of about $2.
Next year, Kentucky will lose almost $500,000 in grants through the federal Violence Against Women Act used to provide legal assistance to poor women who are victims of domestic violence.

Legal services for poor facing statewide cuts
Next year, Kentucky will lose almost $500,000 in grants through the federal Violence Against Women Act used to provide legal assistance to poor women who are victims of domestic violence.

For example, they are more likely to take on eviction cases or domestic-violence cases if there are children involved and foreclosure cases when an elderly person has been the victim of fraud and risks losing a home.

Statewide, Legal Aid will lose about $800,000 in federal funds - a cut of about 13 percent from the $6 million it got this year from the federal Legal Services Corp., which provides most of the money for Legal Aid.
